title: Interactions Among Oceanic Dynamics, Temperature Variations, and Biotic Responses: Implications for Marine Biodiversity Conservation
abstract: This study investigates the complex interdependencies between abiotic factors such as oceanic currents, sea surface temperatures, and their impacts on marine ecosystems, particularly focusing on marine invasive species proliferation and mangrove forest viability. Analyses reveal a direct correlation between stronger ocean currents and increased dispersal of marine invasive organisms. Similarly, elevated sea surface temperatures are associated with enhanced invader success, posing heightened risks to native marine biota. Conversely, these temperature escalations are identified as detrimental to mangrove forest health, undermining their ecological and coastal protective functions. The study also evaluates the efficacy of marine protected areas (MPAs) in curtailing the spread of invasive species, highlighting them as a crucial tool in maintaining ecological balance. Further, the results indicate that ocean currents can negatively impact mangrove distributions by influencing sediment and nutrient delivery systems. The findings underscore the necessity for integrated management strategies that consider these dynamic interactions to effectively conserve and restore marine biodiversity.
